comments.commentBody: I prosecuted mortgage banks for fraud and bribery in Brooklyn neighborhoods and in Long Island as an Assistant US Attorney in the seventies . In 1999 I recommended that Delta Funding not have its line of credit with a major investmwnt bank renewed because its fraudulent practices were obvious. In 2000 I warned two major, now defunct, investment banks that their mortgage origination practices would lead to disaster. Since then Bush and Obama have given a pass to every major financial institution that not only were predatory lenders, but also securities and mortgage fraudsters. The point is, this has been going on for over 40 years! Our Justice Department and the FBI are going after small fry and allowing major white collar criminals to escape any kind of accountability. They did it before, and they're doing it again. Unless people demand action,it will go on and on- and people like this woman will continue to be targets. See www.wallstreetmortgagefraud.com and demand that the law be enforced.

In my opinion, as a former New Yorker -- albiet one who left the city a year before 9/11, the best 9/11 memorial would be to construct a park there. This way, there will be life in the form of nature on a place of death and destruction. A memorial building listing the names of the deceased is important, too, but there should be no gift shop. That would be awful -- tourists shopping for "9/11 memorabilia."

Don't get me wrong: I own some 9/11 books, including Portraits of Grief. However, I did not purchase them at the World Trade Center.

That brings up another point. Can we PLEASE stop referring to the site as "Ground Zero?" I never liked that. I remember when the Murrah Building in Oklahoma City was called "Ground Zero." After 9/11, I never heard that place called Ground Zero again. Are we to forget about Oklahoma City? Of course not. Let's call things what they are, whether they are there or not. Murrah Building, World Trade Center.

One never reads of another 9/11 by product, decency and compassion. When US air space was closed down 30,000+ inbound US travellers were put down in smalltown Maritime Canada where they were fed, bed and cared for by people who would accept no recompense. For security reasons all luggage had to be left aboard so stores and pharmacies just gave the frightened travellers what they needed in the way of necessities. This kindness was kept out of US media while Bush leaked the idea to the Boston Globe that the 9/11 hijackers come from Nova Scotia by ferry, thence to Logan. This is probably a rather startling peice of information for most Americans....the kindness I mean, not the lie about the terrorists eminating from Canada for the lie has roots now in US minds.

I'm one of many working people who must use the Hudson crossings. Some of us have no choice but travel by car. We don't all work in midtown or lower Manhattan.I sit in traffic with others like me: small business people in panel vans, middle class people enroute to a job they're lucky to have in NJ, Westchester, Long Island or Connecticut, as well as nurses' aids, teachers, retail workers, cooks, waiters - and yes, mail room workers. The toll increases affect EVERYONE: Bus fares must increase, the PATH fare increase begins at $.50 per round trip. PATH is a subway-like train running from Newark, NJ through Hoboken and Jersey City to 34th St in Manhattan. Many, if not most PATH & bus riders have a connecting bus, train or car fare in addition to the Port Authority's fee. The cost of goods and services will increase: the truck tolls will begin at $2.00 per axle. And all these tolls will increase to discouraging levels by 2015. Few can expect a pay raise or more business revenue that will match the toll increases. This was a done deal. A despicable deal. Public hearing were announced at the last minute, scheduled in out-of-the-way locations at times difficult for many commuters - who are working longer hours or a 2nd job to make ends meet. The "last minute" toll changes were planned. As a union member (SEIU) I'm ashamed of my brothers and sisters who were planted at the hearings & encouraged to behave like performing seals. We need infrastructure, financed in a responsible manner. Not wasteful projects by unaccountable "Authorities." Sadly, 1 World Trade is not a tribute to our friends who lost their lives in 2001. It's a welfare project for developers and politicians - and the Port Authority Board members. My new tax will be an additional $30 per month come September (total $190 per month). An additional $90 per month by 2015 (total $250 per month). Time to dump the Port Authority. Its actions transfer money out of the economy and into the pockets of the PA's cronies.

Building another WTC is an invitation to terrorists. A beautiful park where people could gather and children could play with a well designed Memorial to the victims of 9/11 would have been a better idea. Too late now. I would not want to work in a building which was attacked twice.

While I agree with the article, the middle class does not drive into NYC. (The middle class will be hurt too, because next time funds need to be raised for something else, they will have to hit the subway fares because toll fares have already been raised too far by this).

Hmmm...well, it seems that these fanatics attacked us because they despise our way of life that allows for capitalism, porno magazines, and whatever else they don't do, and think they have the right to tell others not to do.

In that light, this whole project is senseless. We should have put in a bank, an adult book store, a polling station, and maybe a shooting range, and all the other things the fanatics object to; that would be a statement that we will not let terrorists keep us from exercising our rights regardless of what we do!

Instead we let the terrorists win by curtailing our rights, forcing us to spend billions we shouldn't, and being politically correct.

Where is this country going?

Virgil

Congratulations to the NYT for publishing this article. I hope it raises awareness -- of the difficulty of being a transgendered person, and of this horrible back room practice. Change begins with awareness.

>>anyone who submits to it (let alone as performed by some black market nitwit) has to be completely nuts.
>>simple google search for "silicone injections" ...entries all say "Woman dies from silicone injection.”... have little pity for people who do things to their bodies that should raise numerous and frequent alarms.

You both read the "41% have attempted suicide" part, right? It is agonizing to be a transgender person who cannot afford to change her body. Of course they will take risks that others would not take. And these actions are not the result of vanity, they are trying to meet their legitimate need for medical treatment.

It is very sad. I am a trans-woman, but thank goodness I have good health insurance that paid for my surgery. I have been looking around for safe-silicone injections, but all I have found on the Internet are warnings! Right now, I'll be content with the SRS (sexual reassignment surgery) and the changes that taking hormones have brought. Silicone implants seem to be the safest way to get a more curvy form...sheesh...this article is so scary.

At 67 years old and in her right mind, this woman decided to re-mortgage her home for $82,000. It appears she did not have the good sense to consult a lawyer to read over the contract, but that was her choice and her right.

I am really not sure what is meant by 'predatory lending'. It appears to mean that a fool and their money will soon be parted, as this woman, and many others like her in the same bind, wanted to believe something that was to good to be true, so she took the easy money, then refused to pay the bill when it came due.

I do not see any racism or ageism here, nor do I see why the reason the woman took out the loan, however sad, makes any difference. She wanted the money, she most likely got the money, and she did not pay it back.

That is the only thing that matters.

If a bank made a bad loan, which it appears they did, they will not get paid.

If the woman took out a loan that she could not pay, she should sell her house and move into an cheaper apartment, like the rest of us who cannot afford a home.

In all fairness, that is how this situation and all the others like it should play out. How it should not play out is that the taxpayers or the company who bought her mortgage should be responsible for her poor judgment.

This travesty is being repeated nationwide with few to defend those losing their homes. In many areas it was common practice to target people like Mary Lee Ward. Like Ward, people needed a little money so they were vulnerable to predator mortgage brokers, often befriending the individual, with their lenders who were paid high dollar to deliver them to greedy banks packaging the loans in securitized bundles to dupe investors. The banks originating the loans sold the package and moved on. No risk. In this case, someone blatantly stole Ward's money because they could, thinking Ward could do nothing. After stealing the money, they came back for the house. Thousands of people continue to lose their homes every day because no one is there to see that justice is done for them. Poor people who cannot afford legal representation. Washington turned their backs on those caught in the housing market scam. This is far from an isolated case. In cities like Memphis, thousands of vacant homes stand deteriorating because they are unsellable but homeowners have been evicted. It is bad for the city and devastating to those losing everything.

Congress, the Administration, Geithner, DOJ, all are letting the banks get by with fraud, forgery and theft. Sure the DOJ wants to bring civil suits to recover money for themselves but the Mary Wards still lose unless they have help.

As a columnist I've sometimes criticized teachers unions for not doing more to improve the profession. But the continuing frontal attack on the unions is a serious misdirection in efforts to improve public education.
Brill's book takes this to a new level of illusionary profundity.

The debate is an inane one. Change the cultural value placed on the profession of teaching, recruit the best, support their training, and pay them very highly, and there will be almost no bad teachers to protect. In that world of education teachers unions will be free of the oppression they deal with and be able to concentrate
and finely honing excellence in teaching.

Stop this foolish blaming, which of course naturally stimulates defending, and focus on a more basic change in the role of the teacher.

What's wrong with allowing food stamp recipients to make their own decisions on what groceries to buy? I think it's demeaning and insulting to make restrictions based on the assumption that the poor are too stupid to make intelligent food decisions. My mother went to Columbia and at breakfast my brother and I were both unhappy unless the spoons we were using to eat our cereal could stand on their own in the mound of sugar at the bottom of the bowl.
It's so wonderful to know that I am paying these useless eaters to have steak while I eat chicken (altho I love me some chicken) and now I have to pay for their cokes
